thread.title: Arsenal embarrassments now seem as regular as North London buses, but it still isn't 'Taxi for Arsene Wenger'
thread.title_full: Arsenal embarrassments now seem as regular as North London buses, but it still isn't 'Taxi for Arsene Wenger'

author: Andy Dunn
title: Arsenal embarrassments now seem as regular as North London buses, but it still isn't 'Taxi for Arsene Wenger'
text:
Sport Opinion Arsenal embarrassments now seem as regular as North London buses, but it still isn't 'Taxi for Arsene Wenger' Another humiliation then, but the irony is the display for one half here against Bayern was the sort that will probably convince the Gunners boss to stay Share Sport Opinion Home and away 5-1 losses made for perhaps Wenger's worst Champions League last-16 failure yet (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) Share Get Arsenal FC updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Look on the bright side for a change. 
If Arsenal perform like this on Saturday and keep everyone on the field, they might just scrape their way into an FA Cup semi-final. 
By the end of what officially became a non-event the moment Laurent Koscielny took aim and fired at his own team’s foot, gallows humour was all that was left of another Champions League campaign. 
With Arsenal reduced to ten and parity on the night restored, Arsene Wenger ’s collection of weak individuals reached for the well-worn white flag and Bayern merely cruised into the last eight with a cruel session of knife-twisting. 
Robert Lewandowski’s penalty after the red card offence from Koscielny cancelled out Theo Walcott’s blinder and Arjen Robben, Douglas Costa and Arturo Vidal ensured Arsene Wenger, even in a dead rubber, had the pain of yet another humiliation, another embarrassment. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Arsene Wenger speaks after Bayern Munich humiliation Share this video The 21 angriest #WengerOut tweets after Arsenal lose 10-2 on aggregate 
They are coming thick and fast, like North London buses, but the irony is that the display for one half of this game was the sort that will probably convince Wenger to stay. 
This had the feeling of formality from the moment you read Wenger’s programme notes and the most rousing passage was a tribute to the late Raymond Kopa, the France and Real Madrid legend who worked in a coal mine as a teenager. 
You got the sense Wenger believes it would not be a bad thing if half of his lot had done a few stints down a pit. 
But at least, for one half, they put in a decent shift. 
In the vanguard of a pride-saving manoeuvre that was eventually botched spectacularly were two players whose stagnation has come to symbolise Arsenal’s alarming lack of progress. Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain contemplates Arsenal's seventh straight last-16 exit (Photo: PA) Read More 
Walcott must be the only 27-year-old with over 250 Premier League appearances, over 60 Champions League games and nearly 50 international caps who is yet to fulfil his potential. 
Eleven years as a pro and he can still be described as promising. 
His contribution was pretty typical — unstoppable at times, unwatchable at times. 
At least he embarrassed the most cocksure custodian in world football. 
Nuisance value at pace got Walcott through a cluster of defenders but as he arrived at a tight angle, Manuel Neuer did not seem overly concerned. 
A split second later and he was a study of bemusement, Walcott’s strike taking a layer off the knuckles of his gloves on its passage into the roof of the net. Theo Walcott's opening goal gave Arsenal optimists hope for a while... (Photo: AFP/Getty Images) ...but the England man is symptomatic of his club's problems... (Photo: Rex Features) ...ELEVEN years a Gunner and he can still be described as promising (Photo: Getty) Read More Arsenal legend Ian Wright says they are going through the worst period he can remember 
On his umpteenth contract at the Emirates, it still feels as though Walcott is half the player he could be. Again, symptomatic of Wenger’s later years. 
Ditto Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain. He has been playing half-decently of late, he can see a clever pass and was involved in the move that again saw Walcott in Neuer territory only for his progress to be terminated by Xabi Alonso’s intervention. 
The additional assistant referee could see the whites of Theo’s eyes so was close enough to notice Alonso got a faint touch on the ball before wiping Walcott out. 
It was still a let-off for a blasé Bayern, who had clearly considered this as much of a done deal as the rest of the world. 
A done deal it officially was early in the second half, thanks to Koscielny’s clumsy misjudgement and the Greek officials. 
The Arsenal captain barged into Lewandowski as he shaped to shoot, Tasos Sidiropoulos awarded the penalty and brandished yellow. 
The additional assistant referee had a word and yellow was upgraded to red. Koscielny will now be suspended for Arsenal's next European games... whenever they are (Photo: Getty) Read More JOHN CROSS: Wenger's position is untenable after another sorry European capitulation 
Lewandowski put a kink in his run-up and the kick in the bottom corner and it was time to start the car, time to fire up the Bayern showboat. 
Robben’s left foot thanked Nacho Monreal and Alexis Sanchez for their errors, Costa curled in a third, Arturo Vidal lifted a fourth past David Ospina and completed the double-figure aggregate with a tap-in. 
Arsenal had given up by then, knowing the shame could not really go much deeper, and the natives had headed to the tube. 
But a taxi for Wenger? You still wouldn’t bet on it. 
Bring on Lincoln. Will Arsenal beat Lincoln in the FA Cup? 0+ VOTES SO FAR Yes, but after extra time Yes, but only on penalties No
